intro: Medicago laciniata var. pilosa, commonly known as the hairy sainfoin, is a perennial leguminous plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves that are covered in soft, hairy textures, giving it a distinctive appearance. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in dense, spike-like clusters, which bloom in the summer months. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in dry grasslands and rocky habitats. As a member of the legume family, it has the ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen, making it beneficial for soil fertility.
